awd_titl_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food, Energy, and Water Systems (INFEWS: U.S.-China): A multi-scale integrated modeling approach to managing the transition to sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
As global population rises to 7.5 billion people and beyond, concern is growing about the planet's carrying capacity across the multiple and interacting dimensions of food, water and energy systems (FEWS). The overarching goal of this project is to enable the transition to sustainable FEWS by achieving the multi-factorial assessment of tradeoffs needed to achieve sustainability. This project will build a U.S.- China collaboration framed as a Virtual Research Center (FEWS-VRC) between Purdue University and three Chinese academic institutions (Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research, State Key Laboratory of Hydrology-Water Resources and Hydraulic Engineering, and Center for Chinese Agricultural Policy). 

FEWS-VRC will push the frontier of quantitative systems sustainability analysis in two directions: 1) assessing the role of heterogeneity by extending the use of gridded modeling of agricultural production coupled with land-water use; and 2) analysis of interactions between agriculture and new sources of energy, particularly bio-based energy. The tools developed will be built on a Science Gateway platform (FEWS-HUB) that will provide a quantitative, extensible basis for solving crucial future research and planning problems thus improving decision-making capabilities in FEWS topics within the world's two largest economies. Though the integrated assessment approach, this project will add to existing knowledge in several dimensions: gridded modeling of agricultural production; and coupling of the gridded agricultural model to a detailed general equilibrium model. Spatial models at a national level are too coarse to deal with the heterogeneity of agricultural production. Moreover, as water is ever more becoming a constraining factor for agriculture, it is vital to link agricultural production and hydrological models at basin scale. An expected outcome of this study is a framework to assess the importance of gridded-level heterogeneity as well as potential 'hotspots' linked to water availability. A second goal is coupling the Purdue-developed ENVISAGE Model to SIMPLE-G thus extending the latter model to include energy systems. ENVISAGE is an integrated assessment model with a large energy sub-module that provides an assessment of changes in bio-based energy including land-use implications. Coupling these two disparate models will allow new research questions to be addressed in a tractable and traceable framework. Sustainable development is a globally acknowledged grand challenge problem so improving observational and predictive capabilities in the FEWS framework will have positive impacts on food, water, energy, and national security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: We developed and refined the modeling tools SIMPLE-G and GTAP-SIMPLEG specifically for analyzing the complex interactions within Food-Energy-Water Systems (FEWS). These models represent a significant advancement over traditional economic frameworks by incorporating spatial heterogeneity and local environmental impacts, including heat waves. This interdisciplinary approach not only enhanced the accuracy of economic assessments but also provided a more comprehensive understanding of the environmental consequences of policy decisions. By developing integrated models and conducting comprehensive analyses, our research offers valuable insights into how these systems interact under different scenarios, highlighting differences between the US and China. This knowledge is crucial for devising strategies to improve the efficiency and sustainability of FEW systems in the world's two largest economies and potentially on a global scale. The development of a open-source workflows, codes and datasets  within the mygeohub science gateway further democratized access to these tools, enabling researchers worldwide to adapt and apply similar methodologies to their regional FEWS analyses.

Broader Impacts: Beyond its scientific contributions, the NSF INFEWS US-China project substantially impacted education, training, and international collaboration in FEWS research. The project facilitated the training of graduate students and early-career researchers through specialized short courses held in the US and China. These courses equipped participants with the skills needed to conduct multi-scale and trans-scale analyses of sustainability issues, fostering a new generation of leaders in FEWS research. The curriculum developed under the project garnered interest from universities and research institutes in both countries, paving the way for its integration into educational programs. This initiative expanded the reach of FEWS-related knowledge and promoted interdisciplinary learning among students and researchers from diverse academic backgrounds. Furthermore, the project's efforts in fostering international collaboration were instrumental in building bridges between US and Chinese researchers. By facilitating exchanges, joint research projects, and conferences, the project promoted a global dialogue on sustainable development challenges. This collaborative spirit culminated in partnerships with leading institutions and policymakers, ensuring that research findings could inform evidence-based policy decisions on a global scale.

Project Outcomes: Over the entire life span of the project, the following training opportunities were offered: five SIMPLE-G short courses, one GTAP-SR workshop, and one summer school team project. Over 100 graduate students and early-career researchers were trained to enhance the scientific understanding of complex FEW systems. Two PhD dissertations were deposited, eight journal articles were published, and 22 conference presentations were made. Code, data, and tools were contributed to and made accessible from repositories and our mygeohub online gateway which will continue to be a lasting resource for the global community of FEWS researchers.
